channel.title: Money - Digg
channel.description: Money on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: Michael Jordan's Preferred Whiskey Glass Is A Stunner
item.description: These crystal old-fashioned glasses will elevate your whiskey game.
item.kicker: BE LIKE MIKE (IF YOU CAN AFFORD IT)

item.title: Dark Patterns Could Keep You From Getting Your Stimulus Check
item.description: The IRS enlisted TurboTax's help to deliver stimulus checks. It could cost you.
item.kicker: YOU'RE NOT PART OF THE TURBO TEAM

item.title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Has Put Gen Z And Young Millennials' Lives On Hold
item.description: During our lifetimes, the US has always felt like it was in crisis. I talked with nine young millennials and Gen Z'ers about what the coronavirus pandemic means for their futures.

item.title: Why Fewer Cars On The Road Means California Is Saving $40 Million A Day
item.description: It turns out that having 15,000 fewer accidents per month can save the state some cash.

item.title: 'We're Making Death Dollars': I Drive A Packed New York Bus 13 Hours A Day
item.description: "Nobody is regulating anything if the buses are super crowded. I'm regulating it myself."

item.title: Meet The Rent Strikers Of The Pandemic Recession
item.description: The rent was due on April 1 and these tenants have no intention of paying it — not now, not ever.

item.title: Steve Mnuchin Thinks The Economy Will Bounce Back In 'Months.' That's Very Unlikely
item.description: The treasury secretary's sunny predictions are at odds with mainstream economic forecasting.

item.title: They Filed For Unemployment Last Month. They Haven't Seen A Dime
item.description: Crashing websites, disconnected calls and problems with state-issued debit cards are common for the 1.2 million New Yorkers seeking relief.
item.kicker: 'I WOULD BE OK IF I KNEW WHERE MY MONEY WAS'

item.title: Less Than Half Of Los Angeles County Residents Still Have Jobs Amid Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: Only 45% of Los Angeles County residents are still employed, a national survey released Friday shows.

item.title: A Demonstration Of How Easy It Is For Canadians To Receive Financial Relief Related To The Coronavirus
item.description: The surprisingly simple way to apply for the Canadian stimulus check.

item.title: Resellers Using Checkout Bots Are Driving The Nintendo Switch Shortage
item.description: Motherboard traced some of the recent automated Switch buying to a particular, new bot that anyone can use.

item.title: The Richest People In The World From 1997 To 2020, Visualized
item.description: Bill Gates may have been the richest person in the world in 1997, but here's how the rankings of the world's wealthiest individuals have changed in the past two decades.

item.title: Here's What It Really Costs To Own Or Charter A Private Jet
item.description: An experienced bizjet pilot breaks down the industry, the costs, who can really justify such an expensive luxury and why.

item.title: Everyone Is Trying To Sell Medical Equipment — Even On LinkedIn
item.description: With face masks and other protective gear in short supply, speculators and pop-up brokers are finding customers on an unlikely platform.

item.title: Costco Is Thriving During The Coronavirus Pandemic. Its Workers Say They've Paid The Price
item.description: Costco has long been beloved by employees, some of whom have worked there for decades. But the retailer's decision-making during the coronavirus pandemic has tested their loyalty and compromised their health.

item.title: 'We Went From $85 Million To $0 Overnight'
item.description: The CEO of Baltimore-based Atlas Restaurant Group on operating his 15-restaurant group in a new reality

item.title: Why Hasn't The Stock Market Crashed Even More?
item.description: Wall Street is well off its pre-pandemic highs, but it is also showing a guarded optimism about the recovery. Why?

item.title: Hundred-Millionaire Steve Mnuchin Thinks Families Can Stretch The Current Stimulus Over 10 Weeks
item.description: To be fair to Mnuchin, he's also including small business loans and enhanced unemployment payments, but its still rather tone-deaf.

item.title: How The Ultra-Rich Are Doing Coronavirus Lockdown
item.description: Private jets, piano deliveries and underground shooting ranges: this is what life is like for the 1 percent in the age of coronavirus.

item.title: Where The World's Ultra-Rich Live, Broken Down By Country
item.description: Here are the nations where the people who are worth more than $30 million are residing.

item.title: End-Of-Life Planning During The Coronavirus Pandemic, In Eight Steps
item.description: How to make crucial financial and health care decisions for you and your loved ones.

item.title: Here's What Happens When You Crash A $1 Million Supercar
item.description: Accidents involving exotic vehicles are easy fodder for headlines, but, often, that's only the start of the story.

item.title: Why Millions Of College Students And Young Adults Won't Get A Stimulus Check
item.description: Any person age 17 to 24 who was claimed as a dependent won't be eligible for the $1,200 payment or the $500 child bonus.

item.title: 'Who Wants To Be A Millionaire' Wants To Be A Megahit Again
item.description: ABC has rolled out a celebrity edition of what was once the most popular program on television, this time helmed by Jimmy Kimmel. Can the game show become a hit again?

item.title: Inside Porn Stars' Allowable Tax Deductions, From Sex Toys To Lube
item.description: You may have two more months to file but in honor of the actual Tax Day, Aurora Snow examines the many items that various sex workers can write off on their taxes.
item.kicker: HOW TO WRITE OFF GETTING OFF

item.title: How Coronavirus Will Create A New Working Class
item.description: Experts predict the outbreak will lead to a rise in populism. But will workers turn their rage toward corporate CEOs, or middle-class "elites"?

item.title: Your Coronavirus Check Is Coming. Your Bank Can Grab It
item.description: Regulators have given banks the green light to use stimulus funds to pay off debts that individuals owe them.

item.title: The Best $55,000 I Ever Spent: IVF
item.description: It was worth the loans, the credit card debt and the stress.

item.title: How To Get Your Stimulus Check, And Other Answers To Key Questions
item.description: The IRS began sending out the first wave of stimulus payments this weekend.

item.title: This Economist Has A Radical Plan To Solve Wealth Inequality
item.description: French economist Thomas Piketty says inequality is a political choice. The solution? Wealth taxes well beyond anything dreamed up by Bernie Sanders.

item.title: Can We Print Infinite Money To Pause The Economy During the Coronavirus Pandemic?
item.description: The Fed prints money. What happens if we printed enough money to make sure everyone keeps their job?

item.title: How Coronavirus Almost Brought Down The Global Financial System
item.description: The crisis has brought the economy to a near halt, and left millions of people out of work. But thanks to intervention on an unprecedented scale, a full-scale meltdown has been averted — for now.

item.title: Paul McCartney's Handwritten Lyrics for 'Hey Jude' Just Sold for $910,000
item.description: McCartney wrote the song for John Lennon's son Julian after Lennon began his relationship with Yoko Ono.

item.title: Three Theories For Why The Stock Market Soared In Early April
item.description: A raging class war, a preview of more good news or a simple mistake.
item.kicker: WE ALL HAVE OUR UPS AND DOWNS

item.title: The Coronavirus Has Already Made Us Poorer For Years To Come
item.description: In the aftermath of the coronavirus pandemic, productivity will be lower, households will be more risk-averse, and tens of millions of workers will endure lower earnings for the rest of their lives. And it could be worse if policy makers don't do more.

item.title: Unlike Patagonia, Everlane And Other Superficial 'Mission-Driven' Companies Won't Survive The Recession
item.description: If you can't uphold that mission when it really counts, how much of a strategic misfire was declaring it in the first place?

item.title: The People Who Will Profit Off The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: When COVID-19 recedes, it will leave behind a severe economic crisis. But, as always, some people will profit.
item.kicker: NEVER LET A CRISIS GO TO WASTE

item.title: She Was About To Start A New Job. Then The Economy Collapsed
item.description: We're featuring the stories of people affected economically by the coronavirus.

item.title: 11 Concrete Steps The Government Can Take To Avert Economic Disaster
item.description: Unemployment is higher than it's been since the Great Depression. Here are 11 steps that could help fix it.

item.title: The Wealthy Preppers Riding The Pandemic Out In Bunkers
item.description: "There's one in Kansas that's built in a missile silo that used to have a nuclear weapon in it, and now has a 15-story inverted condominium. I've been calling it a geoscraper. I don't know what else to call it. It's an inverted skyscraper."

item.title: Millennials Are The New Lost Generation
item.description: They're facing a second once-in-a-lifetime downturn at a critical moment.

item.title: How Small Business Owners Survived The Great Recession
item.description: As COVID-19 rattles small businesses around the country, inspiration can be drawn from the stories of those who survived the last financial crisis.

item.title: How The Virus Transformed The Way Americans Spend Their Money
item.description: The coronavirus has profoundly altered daily life in America, ushering in sweeping upheavals to the U.S. economy. Among the most immediate effects of the crisis? Radical changes to how people spend their money.

item.title: A Tale Of Two New Yorks: Pandemic Lays Bare A City's Shocking Inequities
item.description: The coronavirus has laid bare two societies divided on lines of class and race: a divide reflected in skewed death figures.

item.title: Lockdowns Flatten The 'Economic Curve' Too
item.description: Cities that locked down faster in 1918 bounced back better.

item.title: Companies Don't Need To Lay People Off To Survive
item.description: How one CEO saved his 12,000-person company without a single layoff.

item.title: A Long Time Until The Economic New Normal
item.description: Leaders must learn from the pandemic now to position their companies to thrive in the next crisis.

item.title: Nine Amazon Workers Describe The Daily Risks They Face In The Pandemic
item.description: "This job is essential because people need deliveries, but it's also essential for me because I need the money to feed my family."
item.kicker: WORKING TOO HARD FOR THE MONEY

item.title: A Company Promised Cheap Ventilators To The Government, Never Delivered And Is Now Charging Quadruple The Price For New Ones
item.description: Royal Philips N.V. agreed in September to sell 10,000 ventilators to the US for $3,280 each. It did not deliver. But the Dutch company just announced a new deal with the government. This time, it's charging roughly $15,000 each.

item.title: CNBC Anchor's Interview With Venture Capital CEO Takes An Unexpected Turn
item.description:
"Are you arguing to let airlines, for example, fail?"

"Yes."
item.kicker: 'THOSE ARE THE RULES OF THE GAME'
